introduction.p: Möbius geometry provides a unifying framework for studying planar geometries. In particular, the transformation groups of hyperbolic and elliptic geometries in the sections that follow are subgroups of the group of Möbius transformations.

subsection.title: Möbius transformations
subsection.p: A Möbius transformationMöbius transformation (also called a linear fractional transformationlinear fractional transformation) of the extended complex plane \extC is a function of the form f(z)= \frac{az+b}{cz+d} where z is a complex variable, a,b,c,d are complex constants, and ad-bc\neq 0. To complete the definition, we make the assignments f(-d/c)=\infty and f(\infty)=a/c if c\neq 0. If c=0, we assign f(\infty)=\infty.

Note on notational convention: It is customary to use capital letters such as S,T,U to denote Möbius transformations. It is also customary to omit the parentheses, and to write Tz instead of T(z) to denote the value of a Möbius transformation.

statement.p:
Let f(x)=(ax+b)/(cx+d) be a function of a real variable x with real constants a,b,c,d with ad-bc\neq 0 and c\neq 0.
Show that \displaystyle \lim_{x\to -d/c}|f(x)|=\infty.
Show that \displaystyle \lim_{x\to \infty}f(x)=a/c.

ol.li: We have a(-d/c)+b = -\frac{ad-bc}{c}\neq 0 (by assumption), so ax+b\to -\frac{ad-bc}{c}\neq 0 and cx+d \to 0 as x\to -d/c, so |f(x)|\to \infty as x\to -d/c.
We have \frac{ax+b}{cx+d}=\frac{a}{c}\left(\frac{1+\frac{b}{ax}}{1+\frac{d}{cx}}\right). It is clear that the latter expression tends to a/c as x\to \infty.

subsection.p: There is a natural relationship between Möbius group operations and matrix group operations. The map {\mathcal T}\colon GL(2,\C)\to \M be given by \left[ \begin{array}{cc}a\amp b\\ c\amp d\end{array}\right]\to \left[z\to \frac{az+b}{cz+d}\right] is a group homomorphism. The kernel of {\mathcal T} is the group of nonzero scalar matrices. \ker{\mathcal T}=\left\{\left[ \begin{array}{cc}k\amp 0\\ 0\amp k\end{array}\right], k\neq 0\right\}. The quotient group GL(2,\C)/\ker{\mathcal T} is called the projective linear group PGL(2,\C). Thus we have a group isomorphism PGL(2,\C)\approx \M.

Homotheties, rotations, translations, and inversions (see in ) are special cases of Möbius transformations. These basic transformations can be viewed as building blocks for general Möbius transformations, as follows.
Every Möbius transformation is a composition of homotheties, rotations, translations, and inversions.

subsection.p: Next, we establish two Lemmas that lead to a result called the Fundamental Theorem of Möbius Geometry.

lemma.title: Any three-point set is congruent to \{1,0,\infty\}

statement.p: Let z_1,z_2,z_3 be distinct points in the extended complex plane. There exists a Möbius transformation T such that Tz_1=1,Tz_2=0,Tz_3=\infty.

lemma.proof: First consider the case where z_1,z_2,z_3\in \C, that is, z_i\neq \infty for i=1,2,3. It is easy to check that T given by Tz = \frac{z-z_2}{z-z_3}\frac{z_1-z_3}{z_1-z_2} satisfies Tz_1=1,Tz_2=0,Tz_3=\infty. takes care of the cases where one of the z_i is \infty.

statement.p: If a Möbius transformation has more than two fixed points, then it is the identity transformation.

proposition.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Möbius Geometry

statement.p: A Möbius transformation is completely determined by any three input-output pairs. This means that for any triple of distinct input values z_1,z_2,z_3 in \extC and any triple of distinct output values w_1,w_2,w_3 in \extC, there is a unique T\in \M such that Tz_i=w_i for i=1,2,3.

proposition.proof: By , there exists a Möbius transformation U that maps z_1,z_2,z_3 to 1,0,\infty, and there is a Möbius transformation V that maps w_1,w_2,w_3 to 1,0,\infty. It is easy to check that T=V^{-1}U satisfies Tz_i=w_i for i=1,2,3. Now suppose that there is another Möbius transformation S such that Sz_i=w_i for i=1,2,3. It is easy to check that S\circ T^{-1} fixes three points. By , we have S\circ T^{-1}=\Id, so S=T.

subsection.title: Cross ratio
subsection.p: Given three distinct points z_1,z_2,z_3 in \extC, we write (\cdot,z_1,z_2,z_3) to denote the unique Möbius transformation that satisfies z_1\to 1, z_2\to 0, and z_3\to \infty (the existence and uniqueness of this transformation is guaranteed by the Fundamental Theorem of Möbius Geometry). We write (z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3) to denote the image of z_0 under (\cdot,z_1,z_2,z_3). The expression (z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3) is called the cross ratiocross ratio of Möbius geometry of the 4-tuple z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3 (explicit formulas are given in ). The next two propositions give important properties of cross ratio.

proposition.title: Cross ratio is invariant

statement.p: Let z_1,z_2,z_3 be distinct points in \extC, let z_0\in \extC, and let T be any Möbius transformation. Then we have (z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3)= (Tz_0,Tz_1,Tz_2,Tz_3).

proposition.proof: The transformations (\cdot,z_1,z_2,z_3) and (\cdot,Tz_1,Tz_2,Tz_3)\circ T both send z_1\to 1, z_2\to 0, and z_3\to \infty, so they must be equal, by the Fundamental Theorem. Now apply both transformations to z_0.

statement.p: Let z_1,z_2,z_3 be distinct points in \extC, let T=(\cdot,z_1,z_2,z_3), and let C_T=T^{-1}\left(\extR\right) be the inverse image of the extended real line \extR=\R\cup \{\infty\} under T. Then C_T is a Euclidean circle or straight line. Furthermore, C_T is the unique Euclidean circle or straight line that contains the points z_1,z_2,z_3.
The cross ratio (z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3) is real if and only if z_0,z_1,z_2,z_3 lie on a Euclidean circle or straight line.
Let C be a Euclidean circle or straight line in \extC and let T be any Möbius transformation. Then T(C) is a Euclidean circle or straight line.

subsection.p: A Euclidean circle or straight line is called a clinecline (pronounced "kline") or generalized circlegeneralized circle. The propositions and corollaries above show that the set of all clines is a single congruence class of figures in Möbius geometry.

subsection.title: Symmetry with respect to a cline
subsection.p: Geometrically, the conjugation map z\to z^{\ast} in the complex plane is reflection across the real line. This "mirror" symmetry generalizes to symmetry with respect to any cline, as follows. Given a cline C that contains z_1,z_2,z_3 in \extC, let T=(\cdot,z_1,z_2,z_3). Given any point z, the symmetric point with respect to C is z^{\ast C}= (T^{-1}\circ \conj \circ T)(z) where \conj\colon \extC\to \extC is the extension of the conjugation map to the extended complex plane that sends \infty\to \infty^\ast=\infty. The idea is to map C to the real line via T, then conjugate, then map the real line back to C. See .

figure.caption: Symmetric points z,z^{\ast C} with respect to the circle C

statement.p: The definition of z^{\ast C} depends only on the cline C, and not on the three points z_1,z_2,z_3.

Let C be a cline and let S be a Möbius transformation. If z,z' are a pair of points that are symmetric with respect to C, then Sz,Sz' are symmetric with respect to the cline S(C). That is, we have (Sz)^{\ast S(C)} = S(z^{\ast C}).

proposition.proof:
Let z_1,z_2,z_3 be three points on C, so that Sz_1,Sz_2,Sz_3 are three points on S(C). Let T=(\cdot,z_1,z_2,z_3) and let U=(\cdot,Sz_1,Sz_2,Sz_3). By invariance of the cross ratio, we have (U\circ S)z=Tz. Thus we have
(Sz)^{\ast S(C)} \amp = (U^{-1}\circ \conj\circ U)(Sz) \;\; \text{(by definition)} \amp = (S\circ S^{-1}\circ U^{-1}\circ \conj\circ U\circ S)(z) \amp = S (S^{-1}\circ U^{-1}\circ \conj\circ U\circ S)(z) \amp = S(T^{-1}\circ \conj \circ T)(z) \amp = S(z^{\ast C})
as desired.

subsection.title: Normal forms
subsection.p: We conclude this section on Möbius geometry with a discussion of the normal formnormal form of a Möbius transformation. We begin with a Lemma.

statement.p: If a Möbius transformation has exactly two fixed points 0 and \infty, then it has the form z\to \alpha z for some nonzero \alpha\in \C. If a Möbius transformation has a single fixed point at \infty, then it has the form z\to z+\beta for some nonzero \beta\in \C.

subsection.p: Now suppose that a Möbius transformation T has two fixed points, p and q. Let S be given by Sz = \frac{z-p}{z-q}. Let w=Sz and let U=S\circ T\circ S^{-1} be the transformation of the w-plane that is conjugate to T via S (see ). It is easy to check that U has exactly two fixed points 0 and \infty. Applying the previous Lemma, we have Uw=\alpha w for some nonzero \alpha\in \C. Applying both sides of S\circ T=U\circ S to z, we have the following normal form for T. \frac{Tz-p}{Tz-q}= \alpha \frac{z-p}{z-q} The transformation T is called ellipticelliptic Möbius transformation, hyperbolichyperbolic Möbius transformation, or loxodromicloxodromic Möbius transformation if U is a rotation (|\alpha|=1), a homothety (\alpha \gt 0), or neither, respectively.

Finally, suppose that a Möbius transformation T has exactly one fixed point at p. Let S be given by Sz = \frac{1}{z-p}. Again, let w=Sz and let U=S\circ T\circ S^{-1}. This time, U has exactly one fixed point at \infty. Applying the Lemma, we have Uw=w+\beta for some nonzero \beta\in \C. Applying both sides of S\circ T=U\circ S to z, we have the following normal form for T. \frac{1}{Tz-p}= \frac{1}{z-p}+\beta A Möbius transformation of this type is called parabolicparabolic Möbius transformation. Here is a summary of the classification terminology associated with normal forms.

subsection.title: Steiner circles

figure.caption: The polar coordinate grid and Steiner circle coordinate grid
Degenerate coordinate grid lines and degenerate Steiner circles

subsection.p: The discussion of normal forms show that any non-identity Möbius transformation is conjugate to one of two basic forms, w\to \alpha w or w\to w+\beta. The natural coordinate system for depicting the action of w\to \alpha w is standard polar coordinates. See . A homothety is a flow along radial lines and a rotation is a flow around polar circles. The natural "degenerate" coordinate system for depicting a translation w\to w+\beta is a family of lines parallel to the line that contains the origin and \beta. A translation by \beta is a flow along these parallel lines. See .

Pulling the polar and degenerate coordinate grids back to the z-plane by S^{-1} leads to coordinate grids called Steiner circlesSteiner circles.The convention for which Steiner circles are considered "first" or "second" kinds is not universal. Here we follow the convention used by Ahlfors and Henle . In the case where T has two fixed points p,q, the conjugating map Sz=\frac{z-p}{z-q} takes p\to 0, q\to \infty. Therefore S^{-1} maps 0\to p and \infty \to q. The transformation S^{-1} maps radial lines in the w-plane to clines in the z-plane that contain p and q called Steiner circles of the first kindSteiner circlesSteiner circles of the first kind, and S^{-1} maps polar circles in the w-plane to clines in the z-plane called Steiner circles of the second kindSteiner circlesSteiner circles of the second kind
or circles of Apolloniuscircles of Apollonius. See .

In the case where T has one fixed point p, the conjugating map Sz=\frac{1}{z-p} sends p\to \infty, so S^{-1} maps \infty \to p, and S^{-1} maps lines in the w-plane that are parallel to the line through 0 and \beta to clines in the z-plane that contain p. Every cline in this family is tangent to every other cline in this family at exactly the one point p. Clines in this family are called degenerate Steiner circlesSteiner circlesdegenerate Steiner circles . See . summarizes the graphical depiction of Möbius transformations.

ol.li: The fixed points of T are \pm 1, so the normal form is \frac{Tz-1}{Tz+1}=\lambda\frac{z-1}{z+1}. Putting z=2 and solving for \lambda, we get \lambda=-1. The Steiner circles of the first kind are circles through \pm 1 (and the real axis), and Steiner circles of the second kind are orthogonal to the first family (including the imaginary axis).

Solving Tz=z, we get (z-1)^2=0, so T has a single (degenerate) fixed point at 1. The normal form is \frac{1}{Tz-1} = \frac{1}{z-1}+\beta. Putting z=0 and solving for \beta, we get \beta=1/2. It is clear that T takes the real axis to itself, so degenerate Steiner circles are tangent to the real axis at 1.
